@ryanberckmans @Stacks Weird jump to accusations. Stacks is an L2, if you disagree with $MATIC being categorized an L2 then $OP is roughly the same NV FD and the rest of the analysis is the same.
And yes, @placeholdervc holds $STX: https://t.co/8PYgVu4GA6

$STX is worth $1.36B FD NV, or 0.28% of $BTC's NV. A repricing to be on par with $MATIC's relative valuation to its L1 would imply a ~23X, and that doesn't take into account #bitcoin appreciation.

You can do the rest of the dream math ‚úåÔ∏è
Meanwhile, the largest L2 on #Ethereum is $MATIC, which at $12.4B fully-diluted network-value (FD NV) is 6.4% of $ETH's NV.
But because people gave up on #Bitcoin programmability, @stacks has little competition, whereas competition amongst #Ethereum L2s is stiff.

It's no secret L2s are booming on #Ethereum. Arguably, #Bitcoin L2s are more value-add as they expand the programmability of the L1 (whereas $ETH L2s only preserve the EVM programmability) *and* scalability.

With @stacks' upcoming releases not only will trustless $BTC come to the $STX L2 -- $sBTC -- but we will also get hyperchains, which allow for high-throughput and low-latency applications: https://t.co/Z1tIFgB0vN

Ordinals have catalyzed a cultural shift in #Bitcoin that will work to $STX's benefit. For those that want more programmable uses of $BTC, applications built on top of @stacks will provide what they seek.

23/ While @placeholdervc has been a long-time supporter of Bitcoin and Ethereum, we have chosen to support Cosmos and Solana with similar levels of conviction beginning in 2022 because we believe they offer unique, but valuable innovation ecosystems to the mix ‚úåÔ∏è

22/ Current punching-down sentiment around $SOL reminds me of $ETH in late 2018, when $BTC maxis were jeering that its trajectory was to $0.

We all know how that played out... it only motivated Ethereum more. Just as Solana folks are only getting further motivation currently...

21/ But punching down on @solana with overgeneralizations, I find gross. Especially seeing it come from Ethereum folks who unfairly endured the way Bitcoin Maxis punched down on us in 2018 & 2019. Have you learned nothing?

20/ The key for me is are you earnestly working to make things better? To learn from your mistakes? To relentlessly improve yourself, and the world? If you are, I'm all for you, and I see much of that in the @solana ecosystem.

19/ To them, I'd say that having watched the birth of Ethereum and every chain after it, if you're close enough to the inside you know every ecosystem has warts around its founding. Every ecosystem lives in a glass house, because we're all human, and humans make mistakes.

19/ Stepping back for a moment, I understand why some long-time committed crypto-folks are taking this opportunity to step on @solana's neck. Some of them view Solana as betraying crypto's ideals. Or... they feel threatened.
18/ In reality, cryptotwitter is perhaps most driven by price, which can lead to many foolish investing decisions if that's your core information feed.

17/ Furthermore, many dapps were homegrown on @solana, because everything about building on the network is quite different from building for the #EVM. And so what's built on Solana is stickier than most people realize, imo.

16/ Not nearly as many committed teams are leaving @solana as the screaming masses on cryptowitter would make it seem. Instead, they're doubling down and discussing + working together to make the Solana ecosystem better.

15/ @rajgokal and his team remain focused on how to serve the broader set of Solana builders, while not having Labs or the Foundation crowd out innovation, and more broadly I'm seeing amazing comradery & conversation amongst the core builders.

15/ While it has competitors, I anticipate @solana will be *the* blockchain ecosystem known for consensus near the speed of light -- in part because it is the OG to pursue this vision -- and that will attract builders that prioritize speed w/ sufficient decentralization.
14/ It‚Äôs meaningful to me that with Firedancer from @jump_, Solana will be the only network with two node implementations other than Ethereum (correct me if I‚Äôm wrong!): https://t.co/aJfONtTCvU
13/ Meanwhile, @aeyakovenko & the core engineers are maniacally focused on ironing out the Solana network's kinks, making progress on fees, reliability, speed, and decentralization.

12/ In terms of the tech itself, the SVM is novel & performant and I see it becoming a dev standard w/ projects like @Nitro_Labs & @EclipseFND, to name a few.

The SVM can spread more quickly than the EVM did bc the modular stack makes it easier to roll out on diff DA layers.

11/ And as an example, @orca_so reserved less for insiders than most bluechip #Ethereum #DeFi teams. Many @solana teams have NOT gone for the Alameda high-FDV scam launch, and thankfully the ecosystem is rooting out any further of that behavior: https://t.co/aqoLEwyocI

10/ All of these teams are ideals driven, working to build a product that their communities love, and as showcased by @clockwrrk's post, they are all working towards an ethical @solana ecosystem: https://t.co/okWcdwxM19

9/ @Solana-based teams that @placeholdervc works directly with include @vaultapp_ (former founders of @FanDuel), @orca_so (team has Ethereum roots), @solendprotocol (team also has Ethereum roots), and @buildwithnation.

8/ That said, because @solana's ecosystem is not solely crypto diehards, it's rockier in a bear as some of the Web2 folks lose their nerve.

But in terms of building easy-to-use products, & delivering those products to the masses, I‚Äôm inspired by what I see from Solana teams.

7/ In terms of the ecosystem, the dapp builders in @solana are often a blend of Web2 & Web3, which means they understand the crypto-backend, but have the skills to produce front-ends that speak to the mainstream - crypto needs more of this.

6/ And @aeyakovenko's ideological commitment is what‚Äôs needed to lead a community through boom/bust cycles, which crypto endures every few years as the ecosystem speed runs history in a digital context.

5/ Which brings me to @aeyakovenko  ‚Äî while he‚Äôs more pragmatic than Vitalik or Ethan @ Cosmos, which can lead some to think he betrays crypto‚Äôs ideals, I think of him as having an original vision for bringing blockchains to billions that he‚Äôs wholeheartedly committed to.

4/ Some of the devotees are hardware junkies, others are network optimization nerds, the validator community is crazy committed, and generally, a layer deeper than the financial opportunists are builders that get truly excited by @aeyakovenko's vision.

3/ In terms of what I like most about @solana, firstly for me it has its own unique flavor of hardcore devotees & nerds, which means the innovation is independent from what I find in @ethereum and @cosmos, where @placeholdervc is also significantly active.
2/ @VitalikButerin recently asked me what I like about @Solana and so I'll share with the public an adapted & threaded-version of what I wrote to him üßµ

11/ If you get to know @aeyakovenko @rajgokal and the engineers & builders sticking around Solana, you‚Äôll come to see they aren't soul-sucking demons: these are clear-eyed adults building an admirable system at a breakneck pace.

10/ It pains me to see some of crypto's idealism go, but I‚Äôve also come to accept that as the space "mainstreams," we are best off supporting those pragmatists with the strongest value set. The core of Solana is a standout in that regard.

9/ @solana shifted cultural norms around ‚Äúhow to launch a major cryptonetwork‚Äù to a more pragmatic place, not too dissimilar from how pragmatic Ethereum appeared relative to Bitcoin at the time of ETH‚Äôs founding.

8/ There are problematic components to @solana‚Äôs founding story. #Bitcoin, #Ethereum, #Cosmos and other pillars of crypto are not without their warts either, as anyone who's intellectually honest and has been around for long enough will tell you.

7/ Yes, @placeholdervc has established a $SOL position in 2022, as anyone else could, and we're doing that because of a conviction in @solana‚Äôs pursuit of ‚Äúconsensus at the speed of light," a proven ability to execute, and aim to onboard a billion+ to blockchain systems.

6/ There's risk to me doing this; I could be wrong, and ostracized later, but I take the risk because I believe it's worth supporting genuine teams that are doing all they can to move #crypto forward. If they're under duress, all the more reason to lend a hand.
6/ I understand the desire for $ETH OGs to demonize @solana given some of its early backers, Silicon Valley sheen, and creativity around structuring a warchest for itself.

5/ As someone who‚Äôs often identified as an $ETH OG with a keen interest in the ethics of crypto, some of you might be surprised to see me support $SOL as it has been demonized by incumbent Ethereum Maximalists.

4/ My view? The @solana ecosystem emerges from this just as @ethereum emerged from 2018-19: purged of opportunists, with a hardened focus, tightly bonded community, and unstoppable commitment to the cause.

More antifragile than when it entered this bear.

Working with legislations who ‚Äúget it‚Äù is important, but don‚Äôt get hoodwinked by the disingenuous ones.

After years of bashing or ignoring crypto in the hopes it would go away, TradGov is now recognizing the genie won‚Äôt go back in the bottle. And so now the race is on to control it, by ‚Äúfostering responsible innovation.‚Äù
But since this is about control, and cryptography eats at the control of incumbent institutions, there is little reason for them to ‚Äúencourage or promote it.‚Äù

The crypto movement doesn‚Äôt strictly need incumbent institutions like TradFi, TradGov, or Web 2.0.

Of course the support of those institutions, and their distribution channels, accelerates the adoption of crypto.

At the base of ‚Äúcrypto‚Äù is a lot of cryptography that empowers the global population to safely create, custody, and transact information & assets at scale without the need for incumbent institutions.

To foster is to ‚Äúencourage or promote the development of‚Äù ‚Äî with the internet, the US government did that. 

But with cryptography in the public domain, the US government has consistently been antagonistic. 

It‚Äôs about control, and cryptography eats at the government‚Äôs control.

‚ÄúFostering responsible innovation‚Äù is classic government doublespeak. 

‚ÄúInnovation we control‚Äù is more to the point.

This makes some people think I‚Äôm short, but I have *never* been short crypto in my life. 

I work to understand the markets to make my liquid longs as impactful as possible. 

Conviction in blockchains is uncompromising, accumulation is the long game.

Joel and Brad are venture trained, while I‚Äôm public equities trained via @ARKInvest (we all learn from each other). 

And so this bear I have provided a lot of market commentary‚Äî unorthodox for a VC.
There are venture scale opps in the liquids of crypto, and sometimes the opp is greatest there as private market valuations lag the liquids (like‚Ä¶ now).
Placeholder is venture in structure through and through, but even we have a much larger long-only public markets practice than most realize.

On selling: many of the best VCs are not the immediate dumpers retail thinks. If you really believe in something, just because you get liquidity doesn‚Äôt mean more returns aren‚Äôt available. Often, holding smartly w/ tranched selling yields the best result.

Locking up capital for a long time, whether VC or HF structured, implies lots of trust from the LPs, which is tough to earn (implies quality GPs)

Short lockups make raising capital easier, but‚Ä¶ easy come, easy go.

A nuance: fund structures are getting unorthodox. 

There are funds in crypto that provide good venture support, that have a more HF structure. 

Typically notable GPs, strict gates and decent length lockups are a marker of these.

As HFs get redemptions (which VCs in a closed-capital fund aren‚Äôt exposed to), they may also have to dump their positions at depressed prices to meet redemptions, making the bear even worse. 

Smart crypto native VCs would be buying in such a scenario, supporting their positions.

A HF that didn‚Äôt hedge may have a disastrous high watermark that they can‚Äôt get back to for years (no bonuses for yrs), not to mention as their AUM shrinks so too do their mgmt fees, and so there‚Äôs a negative feedback loop of declining compensation and potentially depression.

Structure of compensation in HFs (eg, high watermarks) are important to understand too. 

While a VC won‚Äôt get paid much of a bonus in a year like ‚Äò22, they don‚Äôt have to struggle with a high watermark or declining mgmt fees to pay people to do the work that is vital in a bear.

Good theses predict structural change correctly, and while a little course correction can be helpful, the long term direction never changes. 

Joel and I wrote this in 2017 at the founding of @placeholdervc and it informs our investments to this day: https://t.co/cHJcQtEcAx
Typical VCs don‚Äôt use leverage, don‚Äôt get washed out, don‚Äôt go short, don‚Äôt change their theses with the direction of the wind.
Good VCs are unwaveringly there for the movement, helping portfolio networks & companies with capital, strategy, connections, emotional support, honest feedback.
LARPing HFs give good VCs a bad name üßµ

Of course, teams can change over time, just as people can. But it takes time-- and concerted effort, with proven incremental improvement.

Make your own decisions, take your own risks, none of this is financial advice. I've tried to educate to protect you against common psychological mistakes, and to share how I am approaching things.

We're closer to the bottom than the top.

If you've made it this far, bravo. Now, remember:

~Bottoms are for buying, ~tops are for selling.

Simple as that.

For the longer tail, let's say something is 90% down from ATH. If it falls another 50% that hurts, but in reality, it fell 5% from ATH. Hence, it's imp to zoom out, look at linear charts in bears, & realize we'll reflect on these times as near bottom, even if not the exact bottom

While $10K $BTC could seem catastrophic, that's ~85% down from ATH, the same % drop as the bears of '14/15 and '18/19. So those that survive would have a medal of equal gnarliness to prior bear survivors.

While it should be clear by now that no one knows where *exactly* bottom is, imo we're lucky if we hold $20K $BTC and $1K $ETH in this environment.

If we don't, and in particular if $BTC loses $20K, it's an airgap beneath until a range of supports at $10-14K. 

Expect dead cats.

That said, the global macro situation is the worst crypto has seen, we got to the 200W SMAs for $BTC and $ETH much more quickly than expected, and it feels like there are more whale carcasses to be exposed.

Prices have entered an attractive range. We're around what I expected to be $BTC's worst-case bottom, and anyone who buys quality here is unlikely to regret their decision in 3-5 years: https://t.co/IYxagWPlhr

That's all for now, thanks for reading my mental, permissionless, journal. 

We all make mistakes -- the key is to apply your learnings, try again, and never give up. 

Or take a break if your mind is a mess -- this won't be V-shaped, you have some time.

The more I learn about macro (and it really is endless learning), the more I realize what a pickle we are in. 

This is a good place to start if you're currently feeling lost: https://t.co/2eDTs4Bt0B

An example of a thought amendment, I'd been thinking 2H '22 would be the bottom, but that was a sign of my own overzealousness.

While 2H '22 may give us our first bottom wick, 2023 is starting to look rougher than anticipated & so I'm starting to draw out my horizon & plan.

Twitter is ephemeral, who cares. 

I used to care too much. 

This also applies as we rise into a bull, and keeping your mind open to new entrants / coins.
Lastly, not letting any "public calls" trap your mind into sticking to those calls if the data starts to go against you.

You may say, "Well, you're rich and have unlimited capital." Everyone has limited capital, and capital is very divisible. If you are disciplined, you could divide up a $100 position size in tranches similar to how I size up an 8-figure position.

And if those insane lows are hit, I want to make sure I'm able to deploy chunks of capital as those are the most amazing buys in retrospect. One of the worst feelings is being tapped out at the bottom.

For example, if something goes ~100x the year before, at least plot what that thing looks like 95% down from its peak. 

People will always tell you it's not possible from the vantage of a bull, but it never ceases to amaze how we grind our way down there or at least close.

Also, planning for shock scenarios, and making sure that you always save capital for those scenarios.

I even plot some tranches that I don't expect to have to use (they're greyed out in my spreadsheets), and the position size will be a little smaller if not hit.

Getting disciplined with tranches, where your average price will be w/ each tranche, what your position sizes will be in $ and % of network terms, what multiples and cash on cash that gives you at future price targets, all helps keep you focused, optimistic, and sane.

I'm learning a better balance between FOMO and FOBI (fear of being in) each bear, and each time I'm more patient, but reflect that I can do with even more patience. Aging has a way of doing that for me, luckily üòÖ

There is also a sneaky tendency to deploy more capital at higher prices, and then as things get scary, reign in the amount of capital deployed. Work to at least make it even, and if you're really good, use more capital the lower we go. 

Requires careful observation of yourself.

As a professional allocator in a venture structure I can't afford to miss, and believe the less costly mistake is nibbling a little expensive & then working my way down, rather than waiting too long & not getting position sizes full up.

Position sizing key & underappreciated.

Another learning would be to just give things *at least* 6 months once the parabolas are clearly broken. 

No action can be the best action, even if action feels productive and relieves restlessness. 

Or take the lightest action possible, just to prime the pump.
Can feel the relief rallies getting weaker and weaker as blood drains out of the overzealous.

For example, the first dead cat bounce off the late January '22 puke was pretty difficult for me. 

But in retrospect, it's obvious -- an early bear market rally is going to be vicious to the upside bc there are still a lot of bullish believers in the market.

One of my favorite Jan '22 observations - despite seeing it ~clearly, I've logged some serious learnings already this bear üßµ

And so, while modular will ultimately ‚Äúwin,‚Äù it will be a messy and emotional path to get there ‚Äî that‚Äôs life ‚ò∫Ô∏è

And then, the race to the next evolution of modular blockchains will be upon us, hitting maturity in the back half of this decade. Some winning monolithic chains will adapt, proving the strength of their core teams and communities, others will go down as a couple cycle wonders.

One way we‚Äôve verbalized this @placeholdervc is ‚Äúvertically integrated‚Äù (ie, monolithic) booms first as it has fewer moving pieces that need to come together, but is ultimately surpassed by the compounding innovation of ‚Äúthin pieces, loosely joined‚Äù (ie, modular).

That expansion will be big enough in user numbers so as to prove how some monolithic architectures definitively will not scale. 

But despite that proof, coin holders of the disproven are likely to still do v well.

In the raging debate between monolithic and modular blockchains, it‚Äôs clear modular is the more elegant long-term scaling approach. 

That said, next expansion will be a hodgepodge of architectures, & monolithic is likely to be more mature, potentially taking greater user share.

As an investor in these downturns, your job is to patiently support teams building quality systems capitalized by cryptoassets that will (hopefully) surpass their former ATHs. 

Pretty simple if you zoom out.

Take rising networks like $ATOM, $DOT & $SOL. At current prices:

$ATOM = 4x to ATH
$DOT = 5x to ATH
$SOL = 5x to ATH

At bottom call targets, these maybe hit 10x's back to ATHs.

If waiting all in cash for these, you have to ask, worth it to miss 5x's to perfectly nail 10x's?

Take $BTC and $ETH. At current prices:

$BTC = 2.3x to ATH
$ETH = 2.4x to ATH

If 2017 ATHs become the bottom of this cycle:

$BTC = 3.4x to ATH
$ETH = 3.4x to ATH

If waiting all in cash for these, you have to ask, is it worth it to miss 2.3x's to perfectly nail 3.4x's?

DCA works well for most bc once we've entered a "good enough" price range (which we have), you limit your ability to miss the upside opportunity, even if you don't nail the bottom.

So, for now, crypto is a money-merry-go-round with existing players, and that game will get less fun as liquidity gets drained globally. Then liquidation cascades kick in.

Layer in all the macro stuff and it's hard to make a case for structural buying causing a bottom soon, instead of structural selling sending us to capitulation. 

We are fighting the Fed at least into late Q3 '22, if not Q4 '22 / early 2023...

Meanwhile, you still have funds that are vesting considerable token positions from years past, and fund managers are people too. They're getting scared & will get even more jittery if public markets continue to plummet. That means more profit-taking. https://t.co/T3PyrjmrRi

People get egg on their face for supporting an asset that drops 70%-95%. Can take a few cycles of kicking yourself when things turn around to learn, and for the institution to develop a dedicated team, as opposed to one employee foaming at the mouth about crypto.

Institutions are starting to get flighty. I've been speaking with institutions about crypto for 8 years now, and every bear, the majority that developed an interest in the prior bull lose their conviction in the depths of the following bear.

For now, speculation still fuels most use of crypto -- that's okay, it's how major innovations get off the ground...

...but retail just got destroyed, again. Savings have been trashed with inflation, and the world is scary. Retail's not coming back to speculate anytime soon.

Crypto has improved so much in the last few years, and is unrecognizable from 10 years ago (Silk Road was our best app back then)... yet from a user perspective, it still has miles to go. 

We'll get closer next boom, but those apps need at least a couple years to get built.

For an investor able to operate in both public and private markets, there is always opportunity - you just have to know where to look.
As an example, 2018 was the biggest venture investment year for crypto w/ hefty valuations (at that time), despite the public markets getting absolutely trashed.

Public markets are marked-to-market every second, whereas in private markets it happens once a quarter.

As a result, public markets react much more quickly to new information, whereas private markets lag.

Almost everyone in an industry is incentivized to be bullish. In crypto, it‚Äôs better for their bags, their services, their view counts. 

And hence, commentary is always overweighted to bullishness when the people who ‚Äúknow‚Äù are hedged in some way but silent on that truth.

Forgive me if you thought I was betraying crypto ‚Äî I wasn‚Äôt. 

Truth is, it doesn‚Äôt pay to be bearish. It‚Äôs hard and thankless work.

I‚Äôve been bearish for months ‚Äî the comments have turned from ridicule to ‚Äúwe get it‚Äù or silence. 

From here on out I‚Äôll go back to being the permabull I am, bc altho I expect more pain it‚Äôs no longer the time to de-risk but rather time to add risk thru patient accumulation.

If something quality you hold falls 50%, don‚Äôt think of it as having lost half your money. Think of it as getting to buy double the units for the same amount.

If you have a long time horizon, already we are in money making territory. The worst thing you can do from here is panic sell ‚Äî instead, set up a disciplined schedule of buys, and keep buying the lower we go. 

Everything will work out fine.

Today I believe we stand on the edge of a new age of synthesis. In all intellectual fields we are likely to see a return to large scale thinking, to general theory, to the putting of the pieces back together again.

It is beginning to dawn on us that our obsessive emphasis on quantified detail without context, on progressively finer and finer measurement of smaller and smaller problems, leaves us knowing more and more about less and less.

Rooting about in themselves for the source of their discomfort, they undergo agonies of unnecessary guilt.

Blankly unaware that what they feel inside themselves is the subjective reflection of a much larger objective crisis: they are acting out an unwitting drama within a drama.

Its victims hurl themselves into group therapy, mysticism, or sexual games. They itch for change but are terrified by it. 

They urgently wish to leave their present existences and leap, somehow, to a new life‚Äî to become what they are not.

Today we see millions desperately searching for their own shadows, devouring movies, plays, novels, and self-help books, no matter how obscure, that promise to help them locate their missing identities.

At the middleware and application layer, it's less clear that governance should be used for technical decisions, but more clear that it should be used for economic decisions that affect all token holders.

Leading us back to conclude: the purpose of a token is to govern the token
And while token-based governance is rudimentary right now, the capital-asset that capitalized the system holds the natural right to govern the system (same goes for equities).
(Or we could exist in a zero-profit world, which would also be interesting)

Which takes us back to the token. If there's sufficient surplus -- in other words, user payments are materially more than the cost to run -- then token holders will want to decide how that surplus is spent.

Reinvested? Token buybacks? Dividends?

But ultimately, once the balance sheets are burned down, all protocols will need to find a way to satisfy the following simple equation:

User Payments >= Cost to Run
Any token project gets a giant window of grace to figure its sustainability out because they create their own capital, often sitting on 8-10 figure balance sheets that take a while to burn down.
It's clear to everyone that launching a token is a great way to turbocharge growth in the short term, but it's less clear how that growth can be sustained, and paid for, in the long term.

While PoW-assets like $BTC have little to do with governance, and layer-1 PoS-assets like $ETH 2.0 have clear value-accrual models through the emerging economies they power, middleware protocols or applications-with-tokens are still defining their value models.

The higher up the stack a token sits, the more the token is about governing the token. 

Counterintuitive? Absurd? Only if you think tokens are value-less üßµ
Every winning trade you wish you bought more, every losing trade you wish you bought less.

As crypto gains legitimacy, we‚Äôre back to square 1 in its deployment.

It will be the simplest things that will be most important to teach everyone.

$BTC is an obvious solution to this saving dilemma‚Äîand while some may groan, $ETH too.

But it will be all about education.
In one way or another, this simple notion of delaying payout now for more later, and being right in that discipline, is the primitive requisite to grow resources in a capitalist system.
In the current environment, even if they do save, cash can easily be stolen or extorted. And forget about yield.

To date the vast majority of El Salvadorans have not had a reliable way to save. 

Without a way to save, people have had little reason to delay their gratification and hold out for more later.

Once BTC is well understood, people will have the opportunity to save not just through a mortgage, but just save at all. 

Again, the simplest, but most pervasive things.

While the population is no doubt curious about BTC, a lot of education remains, and Chivo will either need to vastly improve, or (hopefully), open-source wallet implementations will become dominantly used.

Ethereum has a plan to lower fees for a global base of users, while preserving credible neutrality.

Who owns the rights to the fees?
A multichain world is good for competition, which is great for users. The point here is lowest fees possible, while providing all the guarantees we know well.

4/ When buying a Principal Token it trades at a discount to its underlying value due to illiquidity, acting as a zero-coupon bond that will converge on its whole value at maturity (providing a fixed yield).

3/ At the end of a set term (eg, 6 months) each Principal Token is redeemable for its proportional share of the initial stake, while Yield Tokens are redeemable for the yield generated by the principal over the same time period.

2/ How is the cryptoasset offered at a discount?

@element_fi allows users to split the base asset of a *yield generating position* into 2 separate, fungible tokens: The Principal Token and the Yield Token.

$ETH has the cool factor over other layer-1 SC protocols, but its ease of use is lagging some.

$BTC and $ETH are the most popular, ideals-driven cryptonetworks. Many of the competing layer-1 smart contract protocols are much less ideals-driven, and so long-time $ETH devotees feel repulsed.

Sunblock good, sunscreen questionable. 

My skin would be fried if I didn‚Äôt use sunblock. Anyone that says otherwise is LARP-ing ‚òÄÔ∏è

Sunblock (Zinc Oxide, Titanium Dioxide) does not get absorbed into your body. It leaves an opaque coat, like putting a T-shirt on your face, that then protects your skin from directly receiving the sun‚Äôs rays.

Sunscreen (lots of the chemicals ending in -ate) gets absorbed into your skin, which can be more cosmetically appealing, but then breaks down within your body ‚Äî sunscreen breaks down, not your skin, so you don‚Äôt turn red ‚Äî creating free radicals that *potentially* cause cancer.

Don‚Äôt know how this entered CT debate, but there‚Äôs a big diff between sunscreen & sunblock. 

As a lifelong surfer, I use sunblock (Zinc Oxide or Titanium Dioxide) religiously, and avoid sunscreen. 

People saying you shouldn‚Äôt put anything on your skin must not get out much.

Perspective.
@HybridDemocrat A network model is not exclusive to Bitcoin.
And so we'll learn... but it would be a shame to endorse the same social mistakes when we have an enabling new technology that can help protect us... from ourselves.

But, a hierarchy drunk on wealth & power never lets go. 

And so the truth comes out eventually -- the internet accelerates the revealing of truth, one reason why society is waking up to rampant BS in our institutions.

Internally building concentrated hierarchies is tempting as a more paved path that has textbook models, and it's still possible to externally hoodwink the majority into thinking you're building a network (for a while).

Making space for emergent outcomes, as networks do, allows for more complex problems to be solved. 

The world is facing a slew of complex problems, and our hierarchies are not cutting it.

*Time-consistency* is key: consistency of ethos, pathos, & logos allows a network to attract its tribe, and all work towards the most desired emergent outcomes.

Well designed governance, which doesn't have to be a hierarchy, puts structure around this *deliberate process*
Blockchains allow us to coordinate without concentrated hierarchies, though the incentives and rules behind such coordination take time to get right.

For most of human history, we've been subjected to hierarchies for coordination.

In hierarchies, power concentrates & then corrupts, to the detriment of the majority. Always happens.

"If they both achieve 'success,' why does it matter?"

It matters because 'success' is subjective.

#Cryptonetworks are run by crypto-natives, people committed to decentralization of data, wealth & power for the good of all.

#Cryptohierarchies are often run by Web 2.0 or TradFi transplants. While some can make a full transformation, many remain blind to their cultural habits.
Many #cryptohierarchies are parading as #cryptonetworks, but the feel, intent, and distribution of such systems are far from that of a network.

#Cryptonetworks = Deliberate process, emergent outcome.

#Cryptohierarchies = Deliberate outcome, deliberate process.

(h/t @fifthworldzach)

Institutional capital staking behind a network's social signal can amplify the vision.

But for our future, we had better hope the winners are well-distributed by the time that scale staking is needed.

With nascent networks, initial distribution defines key characteristics of who is attracted to that network.

It signals the likely path of the network's culture. 

As a network matures, with PoS we unavoidably need institutional-scale capital to stake behind the social signal.
Should add there is a spectrum here depending on the maturity of the network.

9/ @cjremus @ChainflowPOS is focused on lowering institutional extraction, and I know there are many other efforts (feel free to add them here). 

Values over value.
8/ Once a network is live, reward labor & consumers, not capital.

8/ The dream here is for the everyday person to earn their wages, and store their capital, in cryptonetworks. 

But that requires limiting how extractive a large player can be with their capital. 

Mechanism design needs more work here.
7/ If your liquidity mining strategy is full of institutional investors to pump your numbers, then you‚Äôre missing the point.

6/ As an early-stage investor, we help fund, design, and navigate the nascent stages of a network. 

We are a partner to the entrepreneurs.

But we know our role is as a 3-10 year placeholder, that should get diluted, eventually ceding our place to others.

5/ @placeholdervc is constantly debating where institutions should be involved in governance and earning, within cryptonetworks.

4/ Early-on, people I respect encouraged this type of mining, and this is no swipe at them.

As is predictable at this stage of the market, the opportunists have perverted the idea.

2/ Speaking with a team recently that‚Äôs building on a newer layer-1, they asked us if we, as an institution, *wouldn‚Äôt* stake.

On large fully-diluted valuations, there‚Äôs great variance:

Some will use the un-issued FD value to distribute widely to the supply & demand-side (community owned growth).

Others are using it to hide massive pre-allocated dilution to inside investors.
Relatedly, take extra care with the intentions of communities that have tokens with fully-diluted valuations that dwarf the circulating value.

Emerging from the 18/19 bear market into this bull, some were surprised to find bullish price action after an unlock.

Similarly, when we descend into a bear from this bull, some will be surprised to find unlocks serving as a bearish catalyst.

Large unlocks of tokens are a complex event that interface with market psychology.

Simply put, large unlocks can be bullish catalysts in bulls, and bearish catalysts in bears.

They unlock liquidity to continue the prevailing trend.

@DaveEscondido Indeed! The orchestrator..

In the future, it‚Äôs likely DAO governance becomes more like Docker containers ‚Äî with coordination-legos allowing groups to use a variety of consensus rules according to the type of decision being made, ‚Äî stitching together complex decision trees & organizations.
Right now most forms of decentralized governance in crypto are like mainframes‚Äî rigid & heavy monoliths.
By distributing the decision-making load, groups can more efficiently and sustainably make decisions.

Theoretically, a pod could have a 1 of N voting structure where only 1 member needs to vote for a decision to go through.

While likely only suitable for lower stakes or emergency scenarios, any voter knows they‚Äôre held accountable & so will vote according to the pod‚Äôs principles
In most cases, the mere threat of the stick is enough to get people to behave in line with a group‚Äôs principles.

This isn‚Äôt too far from the philosophical diff between PoW and PoS.

PoW assumes everyone‚Äôs a bad actor and punishes them constantly by making them burn electricity.

PoS assumes everyone‚Äôs a good actor and only punishes them if they violate consensus rules (more efficient).

If someone doesn‚Äôt vote according to the pod‚Äôs constitution, they can be challenged & ejected. 

Assume good behavior to expedite things, then punish bad behavior as necessary.

Credit to @OrcaProtocol for getting me thinking about this more generally.

With Orca, one can parametrize a ‚Äúpod‚Äù such that there‚Äôs a min quorum, time limit for voting, time limit for challenging, and then decisions go through.

Watching some of the boutique investment DAOs ‚Äî which can out execute traditional investment firms due to lightweight gov structures üëÄ ‚Äî this distributed & accelerated decision-making is already possible in some contexts.
Perhaps we haven‚Äôt standardized the right forms of ‚Äúdistributed governance‚Äù that accelerate group decision-making through flexible consensus rules.

Right now it‚Äôs murmured that ‚Äúdecentralized governance‚Äù slows down decision-making.

What if that‚Äôs a temporary truth?

As an entrepreneur, the important thing to remember is that you get to decide what you think is the fairest distribution of the network you're creating, and then find investors who match those values.

To hit this goal, insiders are allocated 20-33% of a network fully-diluted to get it off the ground. 

The permissionless public then receives 67-80% of the initially distributed supply.
For @placeholdervc, the range of what we see as viable today and that would help society move forward into more equitable lands, is outsiders getting 2-4x of insiders.

If a small group of insiders regularly take ~half of the fully-diluted upside (which is common), we‚Äôre seriously kneecapping the redistributive effects of this technology in order to make a handful of people obscenely rich.

While ‚Äúfair distribution‚Äù is a normative judgment, it flows from what we see as a consensus belief within crypto: creating level playing-fields where everyone has a chance at financial sovereignty.

For crypto, an original sin we regularly observe is insiders owning too much of systems that are marketed as public, egalitarian networks.

12/ There are traders much more skilled than myself (I'm a long-term investor, not a trader), who have a more informed view on the specifics and technicals on 1H / 4H / 1D charts.

But my gut tells me to expect a dissipation, and then to keep an eye on the next wave of the set.

11/ It can be tempting to sell the top of an early wave in the set, & whether you do is up to your personal preference and investing/trading style.

As an investor, I know the waves tend to get more intense later in the set, and so I hodl or accumulate through the early waves.

10/ When things are green for many weeks straight, retail tends to believe that will continue indefinitely.

That's when newcomers are lured in by the promise of riches, but often, when we're at the peak of a wave and preparing to consolidate.
9/ Looking at $BTC now, it appears we had 2-3 attempted breakout waves in 2019 and 2020, but the clear breakout wave has been late 2020 into 2021 (current). https://t.co/bX6NpAdif1
8/ A ~40% pullback would be $BTC falling from $35K to $20K. Some would call this the end of the bull, others would call it a healthy consolidation and base to form.

7/ See below how after large green waves we tend to have at least a few, and sometimes a month+, of red weeks.

While these pullbacks look small here, in reality, they represented 20-40% declines in price. https://t.co/rVEGNR9Z2n

6/ As with the ocean, after a big wave there is always a period of dissipation, as the water must gather its resources to let another wave roll through.

In crypto, that dissipation is called a pullback.

5/ Using the weekly $BTC chart, we can see the last bull market (2015-2017) had 2 attempted waves in 2015, before a breakout wave in late 2015, followed by 5 big waves in 2016-2017 (log scale chart). https://t.co/QS0PwTttTA

3/ A useful analogy here is #crypto's bull markets are composed of a set of waves. 

In the ocean, a big set can have 3-10 distinct waves that the pack tries to catch.
2/ That doesn't mean this #crypto bull market would be over, but rather a period to recharge for another wave.
1/ The euphoria is intoxicating, but #crypto is in need of a pullback and consolidation if $BTC wants to reach into the $100Ks and $ETH into the mid-to-high thousands.

What is (wo)man but a quintessence of dust? As great as blockchains are, the essence will always elude tokenization.
"He does not act so as to safeguard his individual interest in the possession of material goods; he acts so as to safeguard his social standing, his social claims, his social assets." -Polanyi

"The outstanding discovery of recent historical and anthropological research is that man's economy, as a rule, is submerged in his social relationships." -Polanyi 

https://t.co/v3wK24kA5g

Everything we do is for our social relationships, which feed back into the relationship with ourselves. 

Often people get confused, that the money, or the token, gets you to the end destination. 

And that end, whether you acknowledge it or not, is love...belonging.

Dating apps are the step before attempts to tokenize love. It's a common complaint that dating apps "commoditize love."

That's right; dating apps make a special connection something that people aim to produce efficiently, like a commodity.

Love ‚ù§Ô∏è is one thing that can't be tokenized.

#EthereumKillers are currently low-cost to use and tend to be faster, opening up access to users that are priced out of #Ethereum (decentralizing) 

However, the economics, governance, and ethos of many Ethereum Killers reeks of Silicon Valley shareholdership (centralizing) ü§¢

Middleware-protocols sit in a really tough position:

#Ethereum is currently high-cost to use, pricing out many users (centralizing)

However, the economics, governance, and ethos of Ethereum tends to fit well with the founding intent of many middleware-protocols (decentralizing)

The biggest middleware protocols (@MakerDAO @AaveAave @compoundfinance @UniswapProtocol @BalancerLabs etc)  currently all exist on #Ethereum, and are being hotly pursued by up-and-coming #EthereumKillers that have money to burn.

Meanwhile, many #EthereumKillers have gone through their "fire period" and are entering their "growth period." 

While many will claim to not be focused on dethroning #Ethereum, make no mistake, the knives are out.

Middleware protocols provide a specific service to the interface layer, be they financial, social, or technological. 

In 2019 @placeholdervc posited they would achieve cross-chain, winner-takes-most dominance in their respective services - we're seeing things move that direction

If building for digital land, remember that roots grow deep with time and labor. 

Quick growing crops have shallow roots that don't #hodl when winter rains fall.

Such speed bumps will slow down the fast-money, but not deter the slow-money. 

If you want to build something over the long-term, you want the slow-money.

Slow-money will be a support when times get rough. 

Fast-money will leave just as quickly as it comes.

If you're upset about capital enriching itself (which *is* a problem), and also a builder, then put speed bumps in the form of time-locks on capital trying to earn assets. 

Lots of examples of farmlands successfully doing this, @synthetix_io even did it through a bear.
I think @BatmanDeFi's #PatienceFarming is a good meme to champion the #TimeMining cause, but I'm maybe too old-school to advise the memery of the new-school ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Something @BradUSV taught me from his experience over decades of working with online networks is that the greatest predictor of how an anonymous/pseudonymous entity will behave is *time spent on a network*
Time is the most precious resource we all have equal access to; allowing people to mine with their time would be divine.
Long-term, really hoping we can flip the #DeFi farming frenzy from requiring capital to earn, to requiring time & labor to earn.
The choice of how and where you operate is entirely yours, don't let the market hijack your being.

And we couldn't be happier, focusing on parts of the #DeFi and #crypto stack that are more suited to our contributions.

Do we forego some returns? In the short-term, yes. But our investments and intents are always long-term.

@MisterBitty_ Lastly, do not underestimate how hard it is to sell your darlings.

If an asset gives you a 100x, that can be life-changing. 

By that time, it will have given your brain truckloads of chemicals that make it v hard to let go. 

But to keep yourself sane, you must let some go.

@MisterBitty_ At the 80-100x levels, some people will exit entirely, others will choose to hold a fraction forever. 

Both work, just know that you'll want some fiat (or stable-ish, widely used MoE) eventually.

@MisterBitty_ For example, take 2x your cost out at a 20x (leaving 18x), 4x your cost out at 40x. Then, from that 40x level you have a 6x locked-in, but 32x your cost still riding. 

At an 80x or 100x you could do similar things (if you have assets that hit those levels).
@MisterBitty_ It is near impossible to exit perfectly at the top, so do it at comfortable levels over time. Get comfortable with foregoing paper gains to protect your principal.

@MisterBitty_ Control your risk and start taking profits (into stable, diversified from crypto, assets) in the mid-to-late stages of the next mania. 

Some cryptoassets are worth holding forever, but if you are 100% crypto now, maybe you should only be 50% crypto by the end of the next bull.

@MisterBitty_ Meditate, exercise, and *listen* to your loved ones to stay grounded. 

If those don't ground you, tune what will ground you now. 

Don't get lost in screens, charts and CT all day.

Make sure to zoom out your perspective regularly.

Ground yourself now; speculation cycles have accompanied promising new technologies for hundreds of years.

While no one can quite control them, we can control how we react, present, educate, communicate & steward the space.

@BalancerLabs is "akin to smashing Fidelity asset management together with NASDAQ‚Äôs exchange, funneling NASDAQ‚Äôs trading profits to Fidelity‚Äôs asset holders." https://t.co/GLfX3NdsQK

@Elationate I think stocks will come to be sourced against these curves as they increasingly migrate into cryptoland (eg, STOs).

But AMMs are a massively deflationary technology, and so in the incumbent financial system I think there's too much profit to be lost in adopting such a tech.

AMMs have grown so quickly that it might be tempting to say the opportunity has already been capitalized upon. 

But I think the opposite: sourcing liquidity against algorithmic curves is such a massive shift in how we think about "making a market" that it's just getting started.
These curves (commonly called AMMs) are the fastest, lowest-cost means to create deep liquidity around an asset that the world has ever had.

Sourcing assets against algorithmic curves, be it for primary or secondary market purposes, continues to blow my mind.

It's not an order book, it's not an OTC desk, it's a curve that everyone can audit and source from.

So yes, Ethereum is a leverage machine, and that is a valuable thing. 

We will see it suck in billions++ more in collateral, and other layer-1s attempt similar strategies. 

Will it go through many more cycles of levaraging and deleveraging?

Naturally. All of life is cyclical.
Superior asset tracking, near real-time pricing, and automated liquidations are qualities that make #blockchains capable of scaling-up and scaling-down leverage much faster than meatspace systems.

But such skeptics fail to acknowledge the capital efficiency of leverage. 

Leverage can be incredibly useful, and is not going away, it‚Äôs only being improved.
Skeptics of collateral and leverage machines rightly point out that they can become fragile and implode, and historically have.
But FWIW, assets designed to appreciate in value, be they capital assets or commodity monies, are naturally suited to serving as collateral and being leveragedüëá

If you can‚Äôt see that $ETH is good collateral by now, then you are choosing to be blind.

It is indeed a leverage machine, and that is a valuable thing.

@AdamPaigge It may not be pretty, but historically capital gets the job done. 

Hopefully, this capital boom is more equitably distributed than past booms... liquidity mining a good step in that direction.
The transition just takes time, but the flow of talent and adoption is only going in one direction. To ‚ôæ and beyond!

Anyone who knows both financial systems will admit to the superior foundation that blockchains represent. 

Otherwise, why would every major financial institution, consulting firm, and tech-giant have their own blockchain research and implementation arms?
There is only so much time and attention that the eight billion Homo sapiens on Earth have, and within that time and attention, only so much capital that can be dreamt up and justified.

If you can see the track that these cypher-economies are on, then you will also see there‚Äôs going to be a long-term war for economic-share between cypher-economies and the meatspace+digital economies of today.

Socio-economic institutions will choose to use cypher-infra for its global accessibility, resilience, cost-superiority, eventual functional-equivalence & novel services. 

Consumers will consume services from these networks, and their embedded institutions, for the same reasons.

Regardless of what happens with individual networks, financial services will be followed by a more nuanced build of various socio-economic institutions, all of which will rely upon this shared financial infrastructure.

While both Bitcoin and Ethereum are decentralized and open-source, and part of the same movement, they are providing different components of the financial services that the cypher-space needs.

Their different "value-adds" will become more & more obvious with time.
21ST CENTURY SERVICES: A unified and global language for assets is what causes some to speak of Ethereum as a future global-settlement layer.

21ST CENTURY SERVICES: For a retail user, sending equities from one custodian to another in the meatspace+digital is at least a multi-day or multi-week affair, whereas on Ethereum that transfer would settle in less than ten minutes.

21ST CENTURY SERVICES: This stands in stark contrast to the meatspace+digital economies, where each asset class has its own exchanges, custodians and fiefdoms, all of which inject capital and time costs into the transfer between fiefdoms.

21ST CENTURY SERVICES: With Ethereum, and so obvious that it might be forgotten, all asset types (equities, bonds, cryptoassets, real-estate, virtual land, etc) speak the same language & so there is fluid exchange between every asset so long as markets exist.

21ST CENTURY SERVICES: A person can now fit near-unlimited wealth in their pocket & access it from anywhere with internet. 

Allowing for the preservation of value through space & time is a sorely needed service for society‚Äôs 3rd millennium (Bitcoin on Mars, @elonmusk?)

21ST CENTURY SERVICES: One of the key value propositions of BTC -- an absolutely fixed supply -- is novel in the credibility with which the Bitcoin network is able to enforce it. 

BTC‚Äôs commitment to fixed supply can be thought of as allowing it to preserve value through time.
@jgonzales19701 Bitcoin is integrated throughout the piece: https://t.co/hRb5u2hooT

FUNCTIONAL EQUIVALENCE: Some will claim that because these cypher-systems are not yet functionally equivalent, they are a toy that will never get there, and should thus be disregarded. 

That would be a grave mistake, as it confuses an instance in time with the longer-term trend.

FUNCTIONAL EQUIVALENCE: Functional equivalence as a pursuit is clear from the breadth and depth of talent that I have seen pour into the crypto space from Wall Street, Silicon Valley, and all parts of the globe over the last six years.

FUNCTIONAL EQUIVALENCE: The rate at which permissionless financial services are popping up and iterating on Ethereum is mind-bending. 

And make no mistake, the DeFi community has functional equivalence as a north star that will be surpassed.

COST-SUPERIORITY LEADS TO UNIT VOLUMES EXPLODINGüöÄüöÄüöÄ

Time and again, low-cost services have taken massive share within our economies. If you believe in the gospel of low-cost, then you better believe in the promise of cypher-space provisioned services over the long-run.

COST-SUPERIORITY:  I expect the margins of these miners to look similar to electric utilities once BTC is fixed-supply, socially de-risked, and a massively used transactional network. 

This is a globally-set margin, for a globally-provided utility.

COST-SUPERIORITY: Similar to Ethereum, users of Bitcoin are paying to access the commodity block-space of Bitcoin‚Äôs 21st century accounting system. 

There's a fee market for this access, where global miners have competitive pressures put on them to keep margins and fees low.

COST-SUPERIORITY: One thing that helps the operators of services on Ethereum is their costs are also much lower. 

You can think of all the applications on top of Ethereum as sharing the capex & opex of the machines that run their operations, lowering the burden for each.

COST-SUPERIORITY: When called, the user pays for the operations & the cost of these operations is set according to the complexity of the transaction for the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). 

Costs that the consumer is charged are commodity costs, with hardly any margin added on.

COST-SUPERIORITY: In this case, that software was built by Aragon and sent to Ethereum's ledger...While the software requires occasional maintenance, which does have associated costs, the ‚Äúdormant but live software‚Äù on Ethereum incurs zero operational cost until it is called.

COST-SUPERIORITY: To use a deep dive example of crypto‚Äôs superior unit economics, it is now possible to run an organization that is functionally equivalent to an investment firm, enterprise, or sovereign democracy for ~$16 a month on Ethereum: https://t.co/WTjGh0rKJ2

In the vein of The Sovereign Individual, the lack of a military needed to keep cryptonetworks resilient & operating, is key to allowing these economies to operate at lower cost over time. 

They require less extraction, because they are lower cost to run & protect.

Together, these macro-and-micro resiliences make it such that no army is necessary to defend a cryptonetwork. Instead, the economics and nature of the network make it such that it is resilient to all attacks, by design.

MICRO RESILIENCE: This is where public-key cryptography has been huge for protecting property, and digital creations, at low cost. Remote seizure is nearly impossible. 

Crypto is building protection-technology, and micro-resilience, into the fabric of online culture.
MICRO RESILIENCE: On the micro-level, resilience to attack is important for the owner of any kind of property. Protecting property is critical to creation in the capitalist-geared world we live in.

MACRO RESILIENCE: There has always been a fixation in crypto on ensuring security budgets of base-layer hardware is sufficient to reliably maintain and append to ledgers at scale...we must protect against ‚Äúdouble-spends‚Äù that could erode trust in the accounting system.

MACRO RESILIENCE: On the macro level, crypto‚Äôs financial system needs to be resilient to attacks of all kinds... 

‚ÄúGiven enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow,‚Äù and the open-source ethos of these softwares works to their security advantage over the long-run.
GLOBAL AUDIENCE: Unlike companies that own or rent servers to provision their services, in cryptonetworks a global set of sovereign servers perform the work for the network based on economic merit.
GLOBAL AUDIENCE: Unlike companies that seek users nation-state by nation-state, in cryptonetworks users are sought on a global basis from inception.

While this cypher-financial system will ultimately arrive at functional equivalence with incumbent financial infrastructure, it will not stop there. 

The base is superior, and so too will the end products be.

This cypher-financial system is targeting:

-a global audience
-macro-and-micro resilience
-cost-superiority
-services designed for the 21st century & beyond.

While the other revolutionary technologies no doubt led to evolution within the existing financial system, none of them built an entirely new financial system from scratch. 

Instead, they remained reliant on existing financial systems, placing power in predictable hands.
In the process of capitalizing itself into relevance, this boom of crypto capital has built a native financial system to account for its very own bootstrapping.
Cryptonetworks have capitalized themselves into relevance over the last ten+ years, with the space most notably reaching for the trillion dollar value mark in late 2017.
We saw this with railroads, electricity, automobiles, computers and the Web, and crypto has been no different.
Speculation fuels capital growth, and with capital a group of people has resources to deploy towards a shared vision at scale.
Financial capital outpaces the installation of new technologies, in part because financial capital is responsible for speculating new technologies into existence.

To expect the *entire* batch of $UMA to sell at the seed valuation from two years ago would have ignored the work and resources that have gone into building UMA protocol since the seed risk-capital was provided. Work and resources provided over time do not come for free.

The other options would have been to cater to centralized exchanges or seek further illiquid and bespoke private market valuations. Tradeoffs are everywhere here, and UMA opted for a novel, low-cost & permissionless price-discovery process.

The mechanism was an attempt to allow the public to set the fair valuation after taking into account the 2 years of work & resources that have been put into building @UMAprotocol since its seeding. It seems to have stabilized around $1.20 per token after > $3M in trading volume.

It's true that $UMA's price increased upon Uniswap listing, and I agree my earlier phrasing about "giving public participants the same entry point as private investors" could have been more detailed, as it was the *initial* entry point that was the same as the seed valuation.

Thanks to @jmonegro & @keighstone for being my mirrors, reflecting to me when I‚Äôm not hewing to the values I purport ‚ò∫Ô∏è

At one point in my very early 20s I gave up all screens for almost a year. 

The sense of connection and appreciation of nuance was divine.
My value system prefers ‚Äúoff-screen‚Äù for all the rich context it gives us, feeding into our animal instincts and desire to belong. This partially explains my drift from Twitter.
Conversing more through high-bandwidth, synchronous mediums (in person, voice, video) is partially the solution.
I‚Äôd love it if we as a society came to recognize values exist along a subjective spectrum and are rarely binary.
Combine the unseen disposition of ‚Äúpresumed superiority‚Äù with social media‚Äôs celebration of polarization, and we have a recipe to always bicker, never reconcile.
Acknowledging varied value systems is particularly relevant bc everywhere I look I see people approaching things from the presumption that their value system is superior.
If you stop trying to always win a value argument, it becomes possible to appreciate all sides of an argument.

Aside from things that I anticipate will clearly hurt more beings than help, I‚Äôve also been working to let everyone have their value system, and recognize its value to them is as important as my value system is to me.

When I encounter a person who tries to force me into their value system and to play a game that they believe is *the* way, I work to remain calm and reveal the subjectivity of their preference. But maybe that‚Äôs me pushing my value system too much üòè
Conversation then becomes a subtle competition, focusing on what we‚Äôll say next to ‚Äúwin.‚Äù We half-listen and empathize little.
Conflicts arise when one person presumes their value system is superior to another‚Äôs, trying to convince the other to come to their side.
Interpretation of your words, therefore, will always be a little different than what you intended.
When you put words out there, they originate from your value system, but are interpreted by every value system other than yours.
Each person interprets the world through their own, unique value system üßµ

If you end up reading @mlphresearch's piece & thinking it sounds like an echo of @CarlotaPrzPerez, that's because Mario both studied & worked under her. While it's great to have a rockstar mentor, Mario's work is original & valuable on its own & crypto is lucky to have him.

While not all roses, @mlphresearch's take on DeFi & crypto is simultaneously realistic & optimistic.

I think he'd agree it's the type(s) of governance and distribution of resources that will make all the difference, per his "field theory" piece: https://t.co/bP40NgcHjf

"To a degree, this also applies to society as we know it today. But globally scalable decentralized computing networks that are systemically important but increasingly difficult to unilaterally control will make it much more explicit." -@mlphresearch

Silicon cage ~ "a society in which a growing # of decisions involve minimal subjective input, instead following a set of abstract, automatically executing rules of 'the system' that itself is too extensive & complex for any single group of humans to directly censor or govern."

"On the one hand, this could bring incredible efficiency gains in handling information and facilitating transactions.

On the other hand, these systems may gradually evolve into a silicon cage of sorts."

-@mlphresearch
"Assuming successful scaling, it may result in creating bureaucratic systems of unprecedented scale in which human administrators are increasingly replaced with machines." -@mlphresearch

"Blockchain networks and the open financial system that is being built on top of them are part of an ongoing drive to hyper-rationalize and automate the¬†global administrative infrastructure." -@mlphresearch

If DeFi, Bitcoin, Ethereum & the rest of crypto continue to gain global social & economic traction, it's inevitable that we will undergo what Mario calls "institutional reconfiguration." We saw the earliest forms of it after the bull market of '13 & again in the aftermath of '17.

"Whenever innovation has enabled new forms of participation in financial markets, it has also triggered institutional reconfiguration, including new regulations to address concerns over consumer protection, market integrity, and social and economic stability." -@mlphresearch

To lend a young industry more perspective, Mario gives examples of ‚Äúseveral instances in modern Western history in which changes in financial practice have contributed to economic transformation and made existing regulatory frameworks obsolete‚Äù (read the piece for those examples)

"In the crypto-financial industry, this is driven mainly by a justified appreciation for technological and societal change ('the old system is outdated'), but also a relative lack of experience and historical perspective given the youth of the industry." -@mlphresearch

"Innovators have a tendency to under-appreciate the reasoning behind the institutional and regulatory arrangement of existing systems, which represent the outcome of a long process of trial and error under constantly changing economic and political circumstances." -@mlphresearch

Recently, I‚Äôve been striving as much as possible to communicate from the heart and through relatable things. 

Listen to what people are struggling with, and then see if there are existing efforts in crypto to credibly fix that problem.
As we move forward, we‚Äôll need to migrate more to the social choices we‚Äôre making, relating the tech to problems society currently faces.

To be effective we need to be self aware. Conversations currently revolve too much around the tech & finance, partially due to the stage we‚Äôre in, but those components are hardly relatable. I‚Äôm guilty here.

Some social problems that are top of mind for me include involving more people in capital accrual, widening shareholder governance to stakeholder governance, improving how we account for nature, and retaining privacy.
If crypto & DLT can show that it provides a technological & social solution to society‚Äôs biggest existing problems, societal headwinds will turn into tailwinds.
Anecdotally, people feel there are enough glaring social problems (many created by finance and tech) that should be fixed before the ‚Äúnext big thing‚Äù is presented.
A headwind we face is Main Street‚Äôs skepticism of finance and tech, and the tendency to provide new solutions to previously non-existent or seemingly esoteric problems.
Crypto is just as much a social revolution as it is a technological one.

If you haven‚Äôt been following the rigor of the debate, I recommend tuning in, and this post serves in part as a summary: https://t.co/mlAVUi8aln

All networks that claim they will ‚Äúdecentralize governance later,‚Äù will have to walk a similar path to the one #Zcash‚Äôs been walking.

While it hasn‚Äôt been easy & an unnecessary amount of FUD has weighed on $ZEC, I feel grateful to have been part of this process as I agree it‚Äôs been ‚Äúthe most sophisticated debate/discussion on post-launch dev funding for a blockchain project in history.‚Äù https://t.co/MMu0P8jwfV
#Zcash is in the most contentious stage of governance: deciding how future decisions will be made.

We think of the governance components of NU4 as a type of constitutional amendment to the #Zcash protocol, and have been impressed with the rigor of ideas and debate that community members have displayed through this process.

8/ Open, and ideally immutable forums (see Politeia: https://t.co/mhV0Yu924v), which show the entire history of a network's decision-making-process and the decisions that were made, are a fundamental building block to setting up a legitimate "writing process."

7/ Sidenote: Everyone can be involved in "read-only" & "light contribution" mode, with a subset of those participants being able to "write decisions" (the ones that have earned the right). 

This involves everyone, while avoiding paralysis in execution of decision-making.

@TwitmeSerifi yes, this underpins our investment in @decredproject, and is also something that I've been impressed with during my recent involvement in the #Zcash community's network-upgrade 4 process (reflection post-incoming).

6/ It's my view that having a transparent & inclusive *decision-making-process* will keep networks robust and evolving the longest. 

This may not be necessary for every network, but it will be for most (governance by defection can work in extreme, antagonistic use-cases).
5/ Decisions around evolving software-based-networks are always going to have to be made, and whether explicit or implicit, there will always be a customary decision-making-process.
4/ Systemic disagreement in the decision-making-process (with no path to remediation), means that community will ultimately lose faith that any future decisions will be legitimately made.
3/ If, on the other hand, people disagree with the decision-making-process, and don't believe it's remediable, then the community has a big problem.

2/ People within communities will always disagree "at the margin" of a decision as we all have slightly different value systems. 

But if people agree a *decision-making-process* was fair, then even if they disagree with a single decision, they'll stay as part of the group.

White papers as we knew them in 2017 have mostly gone out of style. 

And that's a good thing, as protocol and application interface teams choose pragmatism and rapid-iteration over theoretical perfection.

Order of operations for protocols seeking funding has inverted from 2017 to 2019:

2017:
1) Whitepaper
2) Raise in excess
3) Protocol (maybe)

2019:
1) Minimum-viable protocol
2) Raise in moderation
3) Whitepaper (maybe)

[the term "protocol" is used liberally here]

@biserdimitrov @placeholdervc Value of the native asset determines the numerator. In this case, a token refers to the assets issued on top of the platform.

Using #Ethereum as the example, $ETH is the native asset (numerator) while all tokens issued on top of Ethereum is the denominator. But ETH != token.
@ShadySlimFast @placeholdervc this is the greatest weakness of the metric, but our thinking was this: https://t.co/VCfsDWeT5x - certainly, the data can be improved with time.

@placeholdervc 6/ It's long been a discussion in #crypto whether the value of all the assets anchored into a platform can be greater than the value of the base platform's asset (for security reasons).

Such a scenario signifies an #NVTVratio that is < 1, which we have yet to see.

@placeholdervc 4/ The ratio has its own flaws, but our thinking is the market price of assets is the most "efficient metric" #crypto has. 

Dividing the total market value of the base asset (eg, $ETH), by all the assets secured by it (eg, ERC20s, ERC721s, etc), yields a less manipulated metric.

@placeholdervc 3/ A hope here is the #NVTVratio can help us get around faked transaction volumes and other forms of manipulation that have thus far made the #NVTratio less useful for smart contract platforms.

@placeholdervc 2/ The #NVTVratio divides the network value of a smart contract platform by the total value of all assets launched on that platform.

For example, #Ethereum currently trades at ~2x the value of all the assets on its platform, whereas #EOS trades at 234x. https://t.co/g6cg8XXJSt

New metric from the @placeholdervc team to assess relative valuations of smart contract platforms: 

Network Value to Token Value (#NVTVratio). https://t.co/pzMPJBoQJg

So while there is lots to be ‚Äúdone‚Äù during #blockchainweekNYC, remember to have fun and not take yourself too seriously. 

Everything that you do will be undone, and there is great lightness to be found in that realization.
We can think of this using a seesaw analogy. If everyone‚Äôs on one side of a seesaw, the highest leverage activity is going to the side no one‚Äôs on.
Doing new things makes us feel special. And ‚Äúnew‚Äù is always relative to that which is old (even though the old thing was once new).

This is in part because we as social creatures flex on one another by doing new things‚Äî by being in the know. 

We do this individually, as well as on a inter-generational basis.
The more impact you have, the greater the incentive for the *next generation* to do the opposite of what has become the ‚Äúnew default.‚Äù
Everything that‚Äôs done, is undone. Everything that‚Äôs undone, is done again.

4/ It's amazing to have $BTC as the price setter of what's possible for a "protocol" in crypto.

3/ BTC is the market beta of #crypto. 

Every other #cryptoasset is higher beta than it, meaning it'll move more to the downside (when people are panicking) and also more to the upside (when people are ebullient).

2/ Whales cycle from $BTC into the "alts" that're depressed (pick your alt).

Those "alts" rally harder than BTC did because they are higher risk, gaining in *BTC terms.*

The whales can then cash their "alts" out for more BTC than they started with. And so they "make BTC" :-)

Here's the cycle: 

$BTC rallies hard, majority of "alts" drop as BTC is the main liquidity provider to #crypto (right now) and no one wants to sell BTC.

Value of "alts" in *BTC terms* then drops until whales choose to cycle into "alts." Then...

9/ Whereas the ‚Äútruths of capitalism‚Äù are so far buried in our past that society has now forgotten they, too, started as myths.

8/ The "bizarre" factor comes from crypto being perceived as a bunch of radical new ideas. 

Crypto is a myth to most humans, belief to some, and truth for a limited few.
7/ While it can sound bizarre, there's nothing particularly unusual about this process when we compare it with what we see in the capital markets today.

6/ Winning models that become market consensus then start to predict the future.

In doing so, they bend future data into themselves; they become self-fulfilling üôÉ

5/ Put another way, it's the theory follows price, price follows theory idea: https://t.co/6TdvVEpzDh

To be convincing, winning theories will have to achieve data-model fit for the past 1st, and for the future 2nd.

4/ How much value? Increasingly refined models are already emerging to answer that precise question.

As has been the case for hundreds of years past, models will be presented by humans that obsess over the question and the market will quantify consensus.
3/ If the networks do produce services of value, then the cryptoassets that capitalize and coordinate the network will also accrue value.

2/ How well a cryptonetwork can capitalize itself into the future will depend on the sustainability with which it produces a valuable service for society, at competitive costs to other forms of production.

Capitalism capitalizes itself based on speculation that the future holds more than the present.

Through the same speculative mechanism, we see crypto capitalizing itself into existence.

9/ That's the cliff notes, I'll leave the nuances for the paper. Thanks again to @jmonegro @BradUSV @alexhevans @mlphresearch, all of their minds are in the work, and also to @HASHCIB for help in the crafting.

8/ Not only is it important to understand these differences as an investor, but as a builder the means to value capture (or lack thereof) should influence what you're designing, and how you choose to govern it.
7/ Note that ‚Äúannual value flows to supply-siders‚Äù and ‚Äútransaction volumes‚Äù are separate metrics, and serve as the respective linchpin metrics for cryptocapital and cryptocommodities.
6/ Meanwhile, the equation of exchange (MV = PQ) remains our best bet at pricing ‚Äãnon-productive‚Äã cryptocommodities, where PQ = annual transaction volumes using the native asset.
5/ Cryptocapital will take inspiration from its capital asset peers, and as a productive‚Äã asset its value will be calculated as the net present value (NPV) of annual value flows to supply-siders.
4/ Translating this to cryptoland, any asset that is staked, bonded, or otherwise committed in order to get a claim on value flows can be considered cryptocapital.

3/ Any cryptonetwork that requires ownership of the native cryptoasset to gain access to a recurring value stream generated by the network,‚Äã t‚Äãhereby creates a capital asset as opposed to a commodity.

2/ The primary point of bifurcation boils down to what's a "productive asset" (cryptocapital) vs a "non-productive asset" (cryptocommodity).

The equation of exchange (MV = PQ) only applies to the non-productive subset of cryptoassets.

Instead, the paper law would have to coerce the meatspace, to get a meatspace actor to trigger the transaction in the digital space, per the existing rules of the cryptographic law. 

Which brings us full circle to cryptographic law‚Äôs home field advantage in cryptoland.
For example, no matter how much the paper law may demand Bitcoin‚Äôs blockchain rollback a transaction, it would never happen by coercion of the cryptographic law.
But in cryptonetworks, if the paper law isn‚Äôt encoded in the protocol (ie, ‚Äúcryptographic law‚Äù), it has no native say over how the economy functions.
Certainly, paper law can still enforce with authority in the meatspace, forcing bad actors to atone.
In cryptoland, paper law is a second class citizen to cryptographic law.
